statement.text: The great saphenous vein (GSV) is the longest vein in the body, originating from the medial marginal vein, ascending in the saphenous compartment along the medial leg and thigh, and terminating at the saphenofemoral junction. Its consistent anatomic course makes it ideal for endovenous treatment and bypass conduit harvesting.
statement.formal: GSV: Medial_Malleolus → Saphenous_Compartment (medial_calf → medial_thigh) → SFJ at CFV

explanation.intuition: The GSV is like a main highway running up the inside of your leg within a protective tunnel (saphenous compartment). Understanding this highway's route, exits (tributaries and perforators), and the protective tunnel it travels in is essential for treating varicose veins.
explanation.key_insight: The 'saphenous eye' on ultrasound is the key to identifying the true GSV - a hyperechoic saphenous fascia above the vein and deep fascia below creates an eye-shaped pattern. This confirms you're in the GSV and not a tributary, which is critical for treatment success.
explanation.technical_details: The GSV originates from the dorsal venous arch, anterior to the medial malleolus. It ascends in the superficial tissue in the lower leg, then enters the saphenous compartment bounded by the saphenous fascia superficially and muscular fascia deeply. In the thigh, it lies posteromedially, curving anteriorly at the SFJ. Major tributaries include the anterior and posterior arch veins of the leg, and the accessory saphenous veins (anterior and posterior) in the thigh. The saphenous nerve accompanies the GSV below the knee, making stripping in this region risky.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: The GSV lies directly under the skin throughout. Reality: The GSV is in the saphenous compartment, separated from skin by the saphenous fascia.
Misconception: The GSV follows a straight course. Reality: The GSV curves at the knee and can have duplications or anatomic variants.
Misconception: All visible varicose veins are GSV. Reality: Visible veins are often tributaries; the true GSV is deeper in the saphenous compartment.

anatomic_course.origin: Medial marginal vein of dorsal foot, anterior to medial malleolus
anatomic_course.lower_leg: Ascends medial calf in saphenous compartment
anatomic_course.knee_region: Crosses from posterior to anterior around medial tibial condyle
anatomic_course.thigh: Lies posteromedially, curves anteriorly approaching SFJ

saphenous_compartment.ultrasound_appearance: Saphenous eye - hyperechoic fascia above and below creates eye shape
saphenous_compartment.clinical_significance: Protects GSV from external compression; confirms GSV identity

saphenous_nerve.injury_risk: Stripping or thermal ablation below knee

neural_relationships.prevention: Limit treatment to above-knee segment when possible

presentation: Visible medial leg and thigh varicosities
Heaviness, aching, fatigue in affected leg
Symptoms worse with standing, better with elevation
Skin changes in gaiter area with advanced disease
diagnosis: Assess reflux with Valsalva (SFJ) and compression maneuvers
Map tributaries, perforators, and accessory veins
treatment: Preserve GSV if suitable bypass conduit needed

definition.@value: The anatomy and course of the great saphenous vein from its origin at the medial foot to its termination at the saphenofemoral junction, including its relationship to the saphenous compartment and neural structures.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy

learning_objectives: Trace GSV course from foot to SFJ
Describe the saphenous compartment and 'saphenous eye'
Identify neural relationships for injury prevention
Apply GSV anatomy to procedure planning
clinical_pearls: The 'saphenous eye' on ultrasound confirms you're looking at the true GSV, not a tributary
Saphenous nerve runs with GSV below knee - limit stripping/ablation to above-knee when possible
The GSV is the most commonly harvested bypass conduit - always assess before ablation
Accessory saphenous veins are common and can be independent sources of reflux/recurrence
The GSV curves anteriorly at the SFJ - follow the vein, don't assume location

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
